title: Test wanted: ecRecover failure for py-evm

body: @carver can you ACK whether py-evm indeed fails this test or not?
Succeeds on OpenEthereum and Besu too

> Succeeds

The test, or the ECRECOVER call?
The test, it executes in the same way that geth and nethermind execute it

> @carver can you ACK whether py-evm indeed fails this test or not?

Yes, I believe @kclowes is working on this and it has been reproduced locally. She or I will link the PR when it's posted to github.

Did you mean for `hash` and `s` to be the same value? If so, here's a filler file that implements that test.

[ecRecoverFiller.yml.txt](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/files/7125309/ecRecoverFiller.yml.txt)
Here's the PR for py-evm: https://github.com/ethereum/py-evm/pull/2024. I'll make sure these test cases are pulled in too!
That fix doesn't look like it fixes the right thing. The data size is correct, isn't it?
Based on the email that came through, I thought it shouldn't succeed because the r and s values were too long. Is that wrong? I'm new to the EVM side of things :)
Yes the actual values provided in the email didn't match up with what happened when executing the code that was also provio. Could you try the values given in this issue description?
Ah, okay. Yep, will do!
@holiman py-evm does send back an address (3f17f1962b36e491b30a40b2405849e597ba5fb5) with the input from above. It isn't clear to me though why those values/that input should fail?

~~Actually, looks like r and s are too big?~~


EDIT: I deleted the content of this comment because it was wrong. I copy/pasta'ed the wrong secp256k1n locally ðŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸
@holiman why should that input fail?
I was hoping you'd tell me :)I'l try to figure it out.

Ah, okay. Iâ€™ll keep looking too. I didnâ€™t want to spend a bunch of time if you knew!

> On Sep 11, 2021, at 12:51 AM, Martin Holst Swende ***@***.***> wrote:
> 
> ï»¿
> I was hoping you'd tell me :)I'l try to figure it out.
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.
> Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS or Android.
EDIT: nevermind, investigating...

As far as I can tell, it has something to do with points at infinity. It fails this check https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/crypto/secp256k1/libsecp256k1/src/modules/recovery/main_impl.h#L120

I updated the statetest, please try it on py-evm.
Does those tests cover the case enough?

cc @kclowes does the test https://github.com/ethereum/tests/pull/973 'work' on pyevm? 

Also, is there a statetest which implements the one I posted in the issue description @winsvega ?

Yes there is

`GeneralStateTests/stTransactionTest/PointAtInfinityECRecover.json`

That calls ECRecover precompile
@holiman I _think_ so, but need to double check that I'm running the right thing. I should be able to get to it tomorrow.
status?

Fix has been merged and released in py-evm (v0.5.0a2) via https://github.com/ethereum/eth-keys/pull/76. I am working on getting the changes into eth-account now! This issue can probably be closed though. Thanks!
